The moon on Karwa Chauth often rises late, a result of its natural orbit, Earth's position, and celestial harmony.
Karwa Chauth occurs on the fourth day (Chaturthi) of the moon's waning phase (Krishna Paksha). As it’s just four days after the full moon, the moon rises later in the evening.
The moon rises about 50 minutes later daily, so by the fourth waning day, moonrise shifts well beyond the time of the full moon night.
The exact time the moon rises depends on your location—latitude and longitude—causing variations between different cities.
